reviews.review_msg: She's a good prof and explains things really well. She also makes her classes interesting with videos and guest speakers, but she will include this information on her exams. The only think I really didn't like was that her exam questions were often tricky making you second guess yourself no matter how much you knew the subject matter.
really nice prof would definitely take classes with him again!

HSCI 214 - Overall a really funny prof but lectures are boring. He reads completely off the slides and the only reason people go is because they need the attendance marks. The final was quite tricky, because there was a lot of material covered. Take this with him if you're okay with going to every lecture and tutorial!
Amazing prof! Engaging and cares about students. I actually looked forward to class

I met Dr. Goldner back in my first year when I decided to take HSCI 214. At the time I was struggling between my interest for kinesiology and health sciences. This man made me fall in love with health sciences and mental health through his passion and advocacy. I was struggling with mental health problems at the time and his class truly inspired me
A great professor with enthusiasm. God bless his soul and may his  teaching memory last forever. Waheguru ji ki fateh.

I thought maybe I was the only one to write here, but yes he was truly a kind and understanding professor. I didn't do too well on his midterm, but he went through the exam in its entirety and made sure I understood why the answers were wrong versus right. You can't say many professors will do that for you. Rest in peace, Dr. Goldner.

I'm not sure why, but Dr. Goldner truly touched my heart.  I had the pleasure of getting to know him over the past 3 months, and he is the most amazing man.  I will always remember his Matt & Nat backpack as he walked into lecture.  I was so jealous of that bag.  Rest in peace, Goldner.  I hope you know that you helped so many people.

Rest in Peace Dr. Goldner. An intriguing class taught by a brilliant man. Your expertise in the field of psychiatry and mental health made this class engaging and informative. One of the best classes of my degree, and I only wish I made this review sooner. The SFU community will feel this loss for a long time.

Rest in peace Dr. Goldner. May your spirit fly high and you rest easy knowing the thousands of people you have helped through your roles as a doctor, professor, and world renowned researcher. I feel very fortunate to have been in your final class, and to have witnessed your kindness and passion. You are the epitome of brilliance.

Absolutely incredible professor. Ends class early and allows students who have specific questions to come down and ask. Very kind and really cares that his students do well! Course is well structured with 1 midterm, 2 easy assignments, and one final. He wrote the textbook himself so exam questions are verbatim text from the book.

Does not reply to e-mails. Wants you to participate but impossible to get a good participation mark after getting well above 90% on every other component and participating every tutorial and doing the bonus submissions. Dumb grading system, though a very easy class for exams etc

Amazing prof. Heavy participation grade, but if you're interested in the subject the lectures are fantastic. Exams based entirely on textbook questions and are straight-forward. If you're interested in the course it will show on your final grade. Overall great guy, hope I have more courses with him in the future

He's an awesome prof. Very passionate with the material and runs the lectures incredibly smooth. The lectures were long but he always finished early. You have to read the textbook but as long as you do that and do the questions you're good, the midterm was completely text based.  Would definitely recommend. Great guy overall.

His lectures are very engaging through use of guest speakers, multiple videos, and allowing the class to give input. Midterm and final are tricky, but totally doable if you read the textbook. Do the critical thinking questions at the end of each chapter! I-clicker quizzes in class for participation, tutorials mandatory.

Very easy class. Midterm and final were tough multiple choice q's but it's so easy to score highly in everything else that you'll do well. Incredibly friendly professor who knows a lot about this subject

Dr. Goldner is an excellent, fair and approachable prof.  Mental health is an interesting course as it is and Goldner engages you further by involving students in discussion(sometimes even controversial ones) and genuinely respects and appreciates student responses.  Easily one of the best courses I've taken both due to the prof and the material

Every professor should be like Dr. Goldner. Genuinely nice guy and very fair! His exams were a walk in the park if you just did your readings! He also motivates you to speak up in class. I would totally recommend this, because he makes the class atmosphere comfortable enough for you to do so!

awesome prof, took this class in the summer and never went to a class expect for midterm & final and handing in assignments. his exams are based straight out of the txtbook, class is not mandatory at all unless you like watching a bunch of youtube videos. highly recommend taking this course.
Goldner was an amazing prof! Really helpful, down to earth and easy to approach! The lectures were textbook based but very interactive and interesting with lots of videos and interactive questions.

Wonderful prof!!! He really wants students to succeed. Classes were boring for some people since everything he talks about is in the book but I found them pretty interesting. Midterms and finals were all multiple choice with material ONLY from the textbook. We had a lot of guest lectures which helped keep things interesting.

Elliot's lectures are easy to follow and he keeps your attention with a lot of interesting videos. Marks based on 1 mt, 1 assignment, and the final. All of his exams were MC and mostly straight out of the textbook.
THE BEST PROF..!!!

Prof. Goldner is an awesome instructor! However, if you get landed with the T.A. Rose Schmidt try to get into another tutorial! She doesn't do a good job at all as a T.A. and makes this class unnecessarily stressful and can sometimes be very unfair.

I loved this class! Goldner was very engaging and his lectures were very interesting; he's very knowledgeable and genuinely interested in mental health. The 2 assignments were very easy and worth 30%. Midterm was 40M/C. He wasn't around for the final unfortunately. I'd definitely recommend him and I'll be looking to take his UD HSCI class later on.
very interesting to talk to, and he is very engage in his lectures
I really enjoyed him as a prof. Very easy in follow and understand, his midterm was really easy, all you have to do is read the textbook

This class was taught by both Dr.Goldner as well as Dr.Somers and Goldner was less involved with the students so it's hard to rate him accurately.  However, from the few lectures that he ran he seemed like a nice guy who was really trying to engage the students in the lecture.  He also seems to have a genuine interest in mental health.
Solid prof. Community assignment was eye opening.
big picture kind of guy, avoid if you just want the basics
Very good prof. the community project changed my perspective in so many ways!
this was the first time i got exposed to the plight of people with mental disorders. a must.
Quite a luxury to have this type of prof.
The participatory exercise was graduate school level, too complex and demanding. Other than that, great class
Best lectures ever!
Opened my eyes about the problems of mental health globally
Lots of experiential learning. Group assignments very demanding. Worth it in my view.
REally connected to the issue of mental health and passioonate about it. Very tough, which was to be expected coming from Harvard. But overall great experience

The textbook is more helpful than his lectures (15 slides for 3 hours). But the participation grade will force you to stay for his rants unrelated to the course. Tests are all MC. You'll get a good grade but won't learn much. Easy class but still wouldn't recommend.
Awesome prof. Really hard though, so no surprise slackers wrote bad reviews

Sat through 3 hour lectures every week just for 20% attendance. Goes on unrelated tangents &boring to listen to. He didn't even show up to our midterm. Easy mc tests, paper was easy but my TA gave me a bad mark without feedback. I read the textbook the morning of the midterm&final and ended with an A. Pretty chill/easy class though despite the prof

While this was arguably the most boring class at SFU, the exams were easy (all multiple choice) and the paper required minimal effort. As long as you show up to lectures and participate in tutorial you would do fine with this prof, even though he did not really teach me anything

20 slides of notes with very few words for a 3 hr lec. Frequently goes off on rants unrelated to the course. Doesn't help that the participation grade involves asking questions during lecture where people ask unrelated questions for participation marks. Exams are easy and pretty much textbook Q/iclickers reworded. Class avg was a B+.
Lectures are painful to listen to. He over- complicates every concept and is very unclear in terms of assignments and exams. Would definitely avoid HSCI 214 with Daniel.

The course is structured weirdly, but since the subject material is so subjective it wouldn't do it justice to make it memorization based. Dr. Vigo is well spoken and knowledgable and would probably make a great research supervisor. For 214? Just show up and read his slides. I didn't touch the textbook once and I'm going into the final with 93%.

Lectures are boring. Exams are multiple choice, which in my opinion is a useless way of testing us on this type of material. Even though it's multiple choice, it takes him 3 weeks to give us our scores back. Written Assignments taken almost two months to get handed back to us. Won't respond to your emails about setting up appointments to meet.
Dr. Vigo is definitely one of the nicest profs! A little monotoned but pretty interesting class.

Dr. Vigo is a typical pseudo-intellectual, he talks about simple concepts in complex ways and he manages to make an interesting class into the most boring thing. Lectures are hard to withstand but you have to be there for iclickers. Only good thing is that the class itself doesn't require a lot of effort and is an easy A if you read the textbook

Participation is 20%, including iclicker so get ready to participate. He has 10 slides for a 3 hour lecture so you're basically bored, staring at the same slide for the entire class. His study guide was really poor, the tutorials only cover the textbook questions, nothing like the class, but they are the only reason I learned anything so

He's probably the most boring professor you'll ever have. His exams were literally based off the textbook questions and iclicker questions asked in class. He'll bore you to death before you reach the first midterm.

Dr. Vigo made the course easy; midterm and final was MC, many questions were from iClickers! He tends to talk about things not in the textbook (which is somewhat relevant but unnecessary to know for the course) but I guess he had to say things to fill up the 3 hour time slot! Make sure to participate in tutorial, alot of people lost marks there!

A waste of time going to class. Rambles on about irrelevant topics. The only reason people showed up was because of the iclickers. 25% of your grade is based on participation, so be prepared to talk. The textbook pretty much taught the class. Overall, avoid taking this class with this prof.

Drifts off to non-related topics way too much. Doesn't provide clear explanations and grading criteria; it seemed like he was winging it throughout the course and decided what grades were at the end of the course. Only thing that helped me through the course was reading the textbook, not lectures.

professor talks forever about things not related to class/textbook; slides are practically useless as they include 0-20 words per slide, sometimes just pictures w/ no explanation; textbook & iclicker q's will save you for exams; disorganized; iclicker q's are super important. conclusion: honestly didnt learn much and avoid taking this class w him

Vigo is a very passionate professor However, he cannot teach Well he can but very poorly Lectures were useless since he rambles a lot and doesn't follow the textbook Only went to the lectures for participation marks On top of that, he takes a month to release(all scantron)and assignment marks l honestly didn't learn much.

One of the most disorganized profs I have ever had. Took the entire semester to fix i clicker issues, goes on for hours talking about things NOT related to the course. Exam are multiple choice, but the option are so vague. If it wasnt for the Tas no one would have learned anything. Takes forever to give back grades. Lectures are very dry.

Dr. Vigo was such a passionate professor. He made SURE to engage with the student body whenever questions were asked, and even though our lecture was 3 hours long he truly worked hard to make it interesting and was SO engaged about the material. Explained concepts and had a clear grading scheme. PLUS he looks like Zorro, what more can you ask for??

took this last semester and it was hands down one of the easiest courses I've ever taken. test material is all on readings so you don't need to go to lecture (I think I went to two and got a 94). memorize reading material for the midterm, and for the final, he gave the questions in advance so as long as you prepare you'll be good to go!

Don't be fooled by the title. This course is not about mental illnesses (emphasis on the plural), its about addiction. Lots of readings and lectures are kind of redundant and not really required in order to do well on the tests but I would definitely recommend going to tutorials. There is lot of content to memorize, be prepared to read.

The content was very interesting and I personally loved being in this class, however, grades are only based on exams and tutorial participation which can be stressful as you don't have anything else to boost mark. Exams are pretty fair though so I didn't worry too much but it is ALL based on the readings and there were LOTS of readings assigned.

One of the most interesting classes that I have taken under the Health Science Department. Prof. Somers is very passionate about his job. It is not an easy class but as long as you read the articles and attend tutorials then you can ace the exams. Prof. is opens up room for suggestion and improvement! It changed my view about public health.

A fantastic teacher, very accessible, challenged students to think critically, and was very friendly. Extremely brilliant, one of the most intelligent professors I have ever had, but still very easy to speak with, and is able to coach you to form your own ideas and arguments extremely well. A+ if I had to grade him, no question.
he is very disorganized and when he is anwering a question he sometimes goes off on long and irrelevant tangents
Terrible Prof, totally unorganized and irrelevant lectures. Also Takes forever for a response from email.
Good prof
Don't take this class if you want an easy A. Take this class if you want to be challenged to think in new ways. Prof Stern is awesome.
I learned a lot from this course
She made me realize that mental health is a social issue.

Rude, vague, boring, and incoherent.Depth required for a topic covered is around what we already knew before.Exams and assignments have terrible criteria that are hard to understand and everyone loses lots of marks for stupid things. Very picky about things other then content. Stupid overall, coming from a decent student who studies and enjoys hsci
She does not seem qualified to teach this class. Her midterm was a joke, there were at least 6 questions that had more than one right answer. She is not friendly and not helpful.

The topics discussed are easy to understand, however, I would advise taking this class NOT with Pamela Stern.  She is very rude, and inconsiderate of students. We also had to do a "current event" every week with the newspaper, which was pointless.

She is a nice professor. Last term, she decided to use us as her guinea pigs in trying a new teaching technique. 60+ slides per class and expects you to read the chapters of the textbook. Her tests are unfair and not even close to the examples she posts. Final exam was "supposed" to be easy; everyone got either got an F or C+ on it. Terrible.
Nicole Catherine was such a lovely prof to have. She tried her best to engage with her students and is so kind and caring. If you ever get the opportunity to take a course with her, do it!
Ms Palma is able to hold your attention during lectures, and she is very articulate. She is very friendly and approachable.

Palma taught this class with Emily Jenkins. Lectures were kind of dry as both profs just read directly off the ppt notes, but the videos shown in class were really interesting. Midterm + final consisted of MC Q's and were sometimes kind of tricky. The 2 assignments were marked pretty fairly though. Overall, it was your typical 200 level course.

Stefanie is a new professor to teach the course, and I would say that her exams are quite fair if you put in enough effort to study the details. She takes the top iClicker marks, and she is very considerate when it comes to grading. However, since the final average was high, the curve was moved a bit. Overall, she's a reasonable professor!

Best prof Ive had so far. Shes super passionate about her material, you require an iclicker and textbook in this class as well as the novel stated in the syllabus. Her exams are all multiple choice so beware. Her lectures are fun and always interesting! She usually ends early which is a plus and shes very approachable.

Very nice and accessible outside of class - replies to emails super quick. It was her first time teaching so some may consider her monotoned and she does read directly off slides (though she does add her own info every now and then), but overall lectures were straightforward and exams were fair. Would recommend her for sure!
this course isn't as hard as she makes it. Take it with someone else if you can.
SAVE YOURSLEF AND DONT TAKE HER!! you would be better off with another prof

Stefanie was great! For first time teaching (at least to a big lecture), it was clear that she put in time and effort to prepare for each class. Despite errors within I-clicker questions, she was open to hearing students out and omitting problematic questions. Great at supporting in person and email! Highly recommend!
Challenging final and lots of material covered. but i would recommend this class and the prof

She did a really great job! She was very informative and organized. iClickers every lecture but she took the top marks. If you want a good mark you have to work for it, but she is clear about what you need to do to succeed. The exams ask pretty detailed questions but isn't too bad.
shes not a good prof. Doesnt know how to teach. Monotoned. Messes up alot. Doesn't know her own material.

Stefanie is a good prof for her first time teaching, she does tend to just say verbatim the textbook material but she often adds interesting clips; one critique is that she talks way too slow, the lecture slides usually only range from 20-30 slides per section but she takes upwards of 2 hours to get through them; midterm was VERY easy

honestly shes the worst prof ever. Shes so monotoned and reads off her script the entire 3 hours. No clear grading criteria. Messes up alot during lecture and has a lot of mistakes and errors in her iclicker questions and midterms
Most condescending prof you'll ever meet. Monotoned.
Amazing Professor. Loves to answer questions and support your learning. Makes 100% fair tests. Actually cares about his students learning. Nice guy.

Great Professor! He had very clear lectures, good notes and the exams didn't have any surprises. He was caring and super easy to get ahold of. He seemed very passionate about mental health and addiction which added to the course. You don't need to buy the textbook. For exams there is a lot of memorization required but nothing too difficult.

Had Will for Health Science 214 and he was AWESOME. The course itself was interesting and his attitude and just his fun lecturing demeanour was out of this world. If I could take another course with him, I for sure would. He is also very accessible outside of class and replies fast to emails. Genuinely a caring prof.

cant count how many times i fell asleep but i still loved the lectures and him as a prof. he is very interested in the topic of the lectures. saving you $80, dont buy the textbook. his notes are long but i enjoyed reading them. really nice guy. 10/10! will take your upper division class! see you there!

he actually cares about the students and tries to help them succeed in the course. content was interesting and tutorial was actually very useful (shoutout jeanine). everything was easy until the final exam which tanked my grade. definitely recommend this course

Extremely lecture heavy course, if you want to get an A you have to study weeks prior to the midterm/final. Lectures are extremely info dense and are mostly just words on a white background making it hard to follow. I will say professor Small was easily accessible outside of class times and was incredibly helpful before exams, always responsive.
Solid professor, extremely nice person. class is content heavy though

He cares a lot about his student and he tries to create a very respectful learning environment for his student. His lecture is fun and I really love his way of presenting the materials in class. All the content are basically on the lecture slides. One of the best professor I have ever had, highly recommended every class with him!!!

Favourite prof at SFU so far. Truly caring and accommodating, speaks very respectfully and encourages ALL questions and comments. You can tell he is very passionate at what he does. Lectures are info dense and you could get a decent grade with only the slides, A- and above will require textbook readings

Dr. Small is a real gem. One of the best profs at SFU, and one of the best human beings Ive ever met. Super understanding and caring, and he really wants his students to do well. I highly recommend taking a class with him.

Dr Small is probably the best prof I've had at SFU so far, he is so caring and obviously passionate about the course content which makes it more interesting for students. Lectures were dense at times but enjoyable. Assignments were straightforward, he was really accommodating and happy to help. Definitely recommend taking a class with him!
Dr. Will is caring, understanding and really cares about his students. His lectures are straight forward but you definitely have to read the textbook for his exams. Overall, great professor
